reviewText:
Early Access Review

BEWARE - MUCH IS MISSING

Whilst I have recommended this game, I do so because I feel it has potential rather than being a game that I can solidly invest a lot of time in.

The mechanics, graphics, style and atmosphere in Stranded Deep are VERY addictive. I find myself getting lost in the world and trying to do lots of things to improve the life for my character who wakes up with almost nothing and needs your skill and planning to survive.

The issue I have at the moment is that too much of the game is 'missing' or still 'in development'. I realise this is an early access game and that is the point, which is why I have given the game a thumbs up - for now. It seems there was a change in the way the game was being developed and a lot of things, most notably the crafting system, which is the absolute core of the game, have been taken back to the drawing board.

As such, after about an hour of gametime, where you survive, learn to feed yourself and make a bed, there is very little in the game to actually do. Sure you can row your liferaft around to other places to explore and pick things up, but you can't currently DO anything with those things. You can look at them, but can't make a power boat or a raft of your own or anything other than the basic constructions afforded to you in the construction menu.

My biggest concern with the game is - what happens then? If the devs add back in the crafting to make these things... what am I going to do? It's fun learning to survive for an hour or so, but then what? There seems to be a farming thing in development, but I can't see myself coming back to Stranded Deep unless there's more to do. It's a sandbox game, but at the moment the walls of the box are too restricted.

Based on the work that's gone into it so far, I'm encouraged by the dev team and what they are doing. Hopefully my concerns will be allayed and the game will be improved in the new year. It's a great start, but be wary, it's very much 'EARLY' in the early access.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SD is a great idea, and I think is on track to being a great game. There's plenty of potential here, and while it is taking longer than I would like, I do see progress being made. That said, there are bugs. Fires stop cooking, you can get stuck in things (especially fire pits), trees used to, but can't be, chopped, the graphics need optimizing before it can run well, and other things. But from what I've read, and from looking at the bug tracker, it seems the devs are working on it.

Good:
Nice Idea/Story
Very Nice Graphics
Cool Game Mechanics
Excellent Exploration/Open World
Map Maker

Bad:
Story could be fleshed out more
Many Bugs, be they funny or frustrating
Many Features missing or unfinished
I can't find a program to edit the .assets and .resources files; otherwise I'd fix some of these bugs myself.

But you know what? It's an Early Access game. The cons listed here are going to be expected for such, and the game IS playable. Development may not be the fastest, but it is far from dead. I don't regret my purchase, and I look forward to what the future has in store for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, I’ve been putting this off for too long.  I’ve got a lot to say about this game (most of it unironically good), and some mixed feelings about the state of the game industry as a whole that Stranded Deep sums up in an eerily succinct manner.

So, first off, this is not some “lol great uninstall simulator” joke thumbs up.  I really do love Stranded Deep.  By pure happenstance, I picked it up just as a big update hit (DO NOT BELIEVE THE PEOPLE WHO SAY THE GAME HAS SLOW DEVELOPMENT, THEY DO NOT KNOW WHAT THEY ARE TALKING ABOUT!!  IT TAKES MORE THEN TWELVE HOURS TO BUILD A NEW UPDATE YOU IMPATIENT DOLTS!!) and as of right now, the only major feature that isn’t implemented is the ability to be rescued.  A big thing to add?  Yes.  Necessary to enjoy this game to its fullest?  Depending on what you want out of it, no.  The game as it is now I compare to a more serious and survival oriented version of Minecraft.  Where Minecraft is about building as impressive a shelter as you can (in theory) with a survival edge to it, Stranded Deep lives on the idea of survival with the ability to build a nice bungalow on the beach just for the fun of it.  The comparison isn’t perfect to be sure, but I feel it at least answers some of the problems the critics of this game (who have a leg to stand on) have.  One of the most common complaints I’ve seen is that it lacks content and you shouldn’t spend money on it until it has more.  This is actually not true.  Because the game is so aimless, I’d put money on many of these people building 1-6 foundation blocks for a bare bones shelter, built a fire spit, collected some crabs and coconuts and called it a day.  The problem with that is the vast majority of the content isn’t just underwater, but also spread out over many islands.  Like with Minecraft, if you don’t give yourself something to do, like building a big shelter, collecting all the easter eggs, constructing a boat motor, killing a Great White or Marlin, or any of the other many things you can do here and there, you’re going to spend an hour on the game, get bored and shelf the game.  If that’s the case, open world games aren’t for you, I suppose.  And that’s fine.  Me?  I spent 20 hours gathering the resources to build the shelter I have in my game.  And it was a fun and nerve-racking and immersive and lonely and atmospheric experience that I will never forget.  And I’m not even close to done with that world yet, let alone the game as a whole.  That said though, I read the patch notes on the 0.01 build of the game and that ♥♥♥♥’s inexcusable.  Had the game been released on the 0.03H3 patch when I got it, I’d put it on the short list of games that did early access right.  Then again, Stranded Deep probably wouldn’t have gotten this far had it not been released when it had.  Add in the fact that, with the number of bugs still in the game (though rapidly shrinking), I have basically payed a developer money to playtest his/her late beta game, this whole early access nonsense has yet again put a bad taste in my mouth.  I hate early access so much that my friend (who has the average amount of hate for early access) wants to size me for a straightjacket every time it comes up in conversation, so you can see my issues with the nature of Stranded Deep’s development.

TL;DR: If you like aimless, open world games with no goal, as of right now and forever more, Stranded Deep will NOT disappoint.  It’s deeply immersive, atmospheric, lonely, and even terrifying at times if you fear open water (as I do).  If you need more structure then that, wait for the ability to be rescued to be implemented.  That may or may not give you the goal you need to work toward to give this game the time it needs to capture you fully.  I got it for the full $15 asking price and never once regretted it (sans the whole early access thing).  If you’re smarter than me and wait to get it on sale, all the better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game Came out back in Jan, has it evolved.....sorta

Back when I bought this Game near launch I saw lots of promise in this game, I still see that. What has changed since? well the Game was ported over to Unity 5, they add awesome waves (no really they are really awesome), they added a island editor, and the main thing that has happened since launch is that they completely rebuilt the building and crafting system (I am not had so much practice with both of them though, but it does seem it be a big improvement). Over All this game has changed alot, but also has not changed at all. If you still want pick it up in EA ( and did not pick it up before) buy it now, it has alot of promise and I hope in the coming year it reached my hopes that I had for it back in Jan.

Score 7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best survival games I've played so far. No zombies or mosters. Just you, mother nature and sharks! ... yes sharks!

You survive a plane crash and end up in a big ocean full of islands. You have your watch, which is able to track your vital signs, and some basic stuff. You take the raft from the plane and find the nearest island. Finally with your feet on land, it hits you! You need to survive and that's not going to happen if you don't take action right away. So start planning. Find food, water and materials to build your island paradise.

Your only enemy is you and nature.

As you explore the islands, you'll find wrecks of ships and planes. Explore them and go treasure hunting. Not real treasure, gold is of no use on a deserted island. You'll find useful stuff like water bottles, axes and engine parts.

Build your house, traps for catching fish and learn how to survive using just that what you can find. It's an intens game.

Buy this if you like survival games. This is early access but it's really good and fun. One of the best early access survival games out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've tried many crafting/survival games but none of them have stuck, until this one.

I am quite pleasantly surprised actually, when I got it I wasn't expecting it to be much especially in early access. But this game is fun. The streamlined crafting system and the constant need to explore really makes this enjoyable to play. Graphically it looks amazing, especially the detail of the ocean floor. It feels very immersive. It is Cast Away the game (watch the movie).

Still plenty more content to be added within the next year or so which should make it even better. But even as is there is enough content to keep you entertain for a while. Then once you are done with that you can jump into the wonderful modding community, who have created some awesome mods to mess around with.

Great game! I've played 60hrs, ....before the experiment update!
For those that say this gets boring, go look for some of the rare items you can find! This game is about staying alive, every single day....as long as possible. (until someday there may be a way out). You will run out of food no matter how much you have stock piled, you will run out of wood, water, tools. So i don't know how you can be bored when there is always something to do to keep yourself going on. Now that the test update is out, it's even harder to go diving for items!! Which is cool, and more life-like in my opinion. Though i do think there would be some calm ocean days in the ocean, but mostly rough as i've experienced so far. For those that don't have a compass, and are already crying about things in the game because of no compass, there is a compass, and it works great! Never lose your home base again! Another rare item i found was a Dead-Ex package,.. (instead of Fed-Ex). Not sure what it all means but it's a mystery so far. Great job on the water update, wish things were moving along a little faster, or at least working more in the new update with the rough ocean. First time trying the experiment update, my raft flipped a shark was attacking me at the same time, waves are crazy, and i'm trying to get back on my raft,.... raft was upside down so had to paddle back as it was to shore, then flip my raft back over once grounded. I like the click and drag movement in this game, many developers could learn a lot from these guys on that! It's so efficent, and when you can't carry any more things, ...just drag one along!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played this game for..around 60 hours. Mint game. No complaints. It's an early access game, gives you the thrill of new updates and watching is grow into something amazing. The graphics for a 2 dev team (BeamTeam) are supurb. The realism is improving constently. The environment (trees, shrubs, animals ect) is fantastic and getting better with every update. (mini spoiler) Killed a shark and dragged it onto the beach JUST to look at how realistic it looked. Was like yup definitely a black tip. For now there isn't much content (however will be more in the near future obviously). Few flaws in the game (example, items not funtioning properly or at all) but I won't throw the game nor devs under the bus for that. Need to remember it's Early Access. Great game to muck around, build to your heart's content. Definitely recommend this game (doesnt cost too much) and you get a lot of hours into it. create your own island how you want to, put it into your game so you can play around on it. Even create a new world with a random new seed and start again in a completely different set up. Go on and buy it :3

ps. when needing help the forums are replied to in just a few hours or less. It's great to get good service from devs and moderators :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic Start!

I arrived on my first island, found a rock, cut up a small plant into lashing and found a stick to build myself a rudentary axe.  I then used that axe to cut down a palm tree, cut up the trees trunk into logs, cut those logs into sticks and started work on building a home for myself.

The physical crafting system is great and the effort required to build and the process involved is hugely satisying.

Ive only scratched the surface (pun intended) but the exploration underwater is awesome.  The sharks can be a bit relentless at times, but they add tension and fear to searching sunken ships and other oddities lying below the surface.

Its early in its development so I am overlooking issues and glitches that go with it. It is fun and it feel like the developers have a pashion for their game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIts amazing! Now I'm a big fan of games where you have to survive the enviornment,but this one takes the cake! Now at first it took me a little bit to figure out the controls but in five minutes I had them mastered. There is nothing I dislike about this game for everything is great, the graphics, gameplay, mechanics, everything! I love the reandomly generated maps and the extremely realisitc graphics. Although my computer makes the game slow for this, itis worth it! Proboably my favorite thing about this game is that when you build a house it doesn't come out looking like a luxury hotel, it looks like what a house you built yourself with little resources on an island might actually look like (Iv'e been lucky enough to never be in this situation!)
